Criminal Rights: Evidence : Regulates searches and seizures, particularly in criminal investigations. May also prohibit the admission of involuntary confessions, or other suspect forms of evidence.
Political Rights: Expropriation of Property : Prohibits the government from taking private property without compensation.
Religious and Expressive Rights: Equality : Guarantees individuals equality before the law.
Economic Rights: Fair Compensation : Guarantees just, fair, or equal payment for work.
Social Rights: Shelter : Grants individuals the right to adequate shelter or housing.
Aspirational Rights: Human Dignity : "Dignity of man" or "human dignity" mentioned in the constitution. Often used as a motivation or justification for constitutional provisions.

Criminal Rights: Unjustified Restraint : Protects individuals from arbitrary detention or unjustified arrest. Sometimes known as habeas corpus.
Political Rights: Life : Grants individuals the right to life. May or may not reference rights of the unborn.
Religious and Expressive Rights: Reputation : Grants individuals the right to protect themselves against libel or slander.
Economic Rights: Unions : Grants individuals the right to form trade unions.
Social Rights: Marriage : Grants individuals the right to marry. May be limited to heterosexual couples.
Aspirational Rights: Provide Work : Obliges state to provide work.

Criminal Rights: Due Process : Entitles defendants to have their cases heard according to legal procedure.
Political Rights: Slavery : Forbids ownership of human beings.
Religious and Expressive Rights: Freedom of Religion : Grants individuals the right to hold and practice religious beliefs.
Economic Rights: Strike : Grants individuals the right to strike. May also include protection for strikers' jobs or income.
Social Rights: Privacy : Forbids government intrusion into individuals' property, persons, or communications without proper authorization.
Aspirational Rights: Self-Determination : Grants groups of individuals the right to self-determination. May reference the nation as a whole, or specific groups of individuals.`

Criminal Rights: Capital Punishment : Forbids the state from imposing the death penalty.
Political Rights: Petition : Grants individuals the right to petition the government.
Religious and Expressive Rights: Church/State Relationship : Guarantees some degree of separation between church and state.
Economic Rights: Transfer Property : Grants individuals the right to freely transfer property.
Social Rights: Renounce Citizenship : Grants individuals the right to renounce their citizenship.
Aspirational Rights: Development of Person : Grants individuals the right to develop and express their own personality.

Criminal Rights: Presumption of Innocence : Requires criminal defendants to be viewed as innocent until proven guilty. This requirement places the burden of proof on the prosecution.
Political Rights: Assembly : Grants individuals and groups the right to assemble in public places for legal purposes. Often linked with the right to protest.
Religious and Expressive Rights: Opinion : Grants individuals freedom of opinion, thought, or conscience. Distinct from freedom of expression.
Economic Rights: Consumer Rights : Grants special rights to consumers. May include protection from harmful products or unethical business practices.
Social Rights: Birthright Citizenship : Provides right to citizenship upon birth to certain individuals. This right is usually subject to certain requirements, such as location of birth or parents' citizenship status.
Aspirational Rights: Environment : Obligates both citizens and the state to protect or preserve the environment.

Criminal Rights: Cruel and Unusual Punishment : Forbids cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment.
Political Rights: Arms : Grants individuals the right to possess firearms and other weapons. May be subject to restrictions on use, transportation, or type of weapon.
Religious and Expressive Rights: Expression : Grants individuals the right to express themselves.
Economic Rights: Property : Grants individuals and corporations the right to own property, or general protection of property ownership.
Social Rights: Association : Grants individuals the right to enter voluntary associations.
Aspirational Rights: Overthrow Government : Grants citizens right to depose the government under certain circumstances.

Criminal Rights: Jury : Grants individuals the right to trial by jury.
Political Rights: Form Parties : Protects right to form or join political parties.
Religious and Expressive Rights: Conscientious Objectors : Grants religious or ethical objectors an exemption from combat duty. May require noncombat service instead.
Economic Rights: Occupation : Grants individuals the freedom to choose their occupation without government interference.
Social Rights: Social Security : Social security mentioned. Reference may be general, or may specifically include a national pension scheme.
Aspirational Rights: Health : Grants individuals the right to health. May also include a state obligation to provide healthcare.

Criminal Rights: Counsel : Grants accused individuals the right to legal counsel.
Political Rights: Suffrage : References expansion of voting rights to new groups.
Religious and Expressive Rights: Press : Grants individuals the right to free expression in all forms of media.
Economic Rights: Safe Working Environment : Grants individuals the right to a safe working environment. May include government obligation to provide safe working conditions.
Social Rights: Leisure : Grants individuals the right to vacations or weekly holidays.
Aspirational Rights: Free Education : Obligates the state to provide free education. May only apply up to a certain age or level of educational attainment.

Criminal Rights: Victim's Rights : Grants the victims of crimes special rights in the justice process. Examples include restitution, attendance at the trial, or opportunity to speak at the trial.
Political Rights: Torture : Forbids the state from torturing individuals. Torture may be allowed during times of war or crisis.
Religious and Expressive Rights: Movement : Grants individuals the right to travel within or out of the state.
Economic Rights: Free Market : Protects individuals and corporations from price-fixing, monopolies, and other anti-competitive strategies.
Aspirational Rights: Standard of Living : Grants individuals the right to a minimum standard of living. Often linked to guarantees of human dignity.
